questions.text: A 30-year-old male develops respiratory distress, confusion, and a chest petechial rash two days after surgery for multiple long bone fractures from a motor vehicle accident. Suspecting Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES), which diagnostic test is used to detect fat in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)

 

Explanation:
Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is the modality specifically used to detect fat in the form of lipid-laden macrophages, which is important for the diagnosis of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES).

Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) Investigations:

 

Chest Radiographs:

Increasing diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates within 24-48 hours post onset.

Head CT (non-contrast):

Normal or diffuse petechial haemorrhages in white matter, reflecting microvascular injury.

Helical chest CT:


 
  • It may appear normal if embolic particles lodge in capillary beds.
  • Ground-glass opacities and nodular opacities are common findings in trauma, indicating fat embolism.
  • Ground-glass opacities involving over 75% of lung parenchyma with consolidation indicate severe disease.
embolism CT crazy paving pattern.jpg" data-author="" data-hash="9420" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/LD405xrVuTrWbviL1apc1744377265.png" />

HRCT image demonstrates bilateral ground-glass opacities and interlobular septal thickening resulting in the crazy-paving pattern. Note the sharp margins between the parenchymal abnormalities and areas of normal lung (white arrows) with areas of lobular sparing (black arrows).

Intracranial Doppler Ultrasonography:

Detects cerebral microembolic signals up to 4 days post-injury.

Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE):
  • Visualises emboli release during long-bone fracture repair surgeries.
  • Associated with increased right heart and pulmonary artery pressures; correlation with FES development is unclear.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL):

The presence of lipid inclusions (≤5% fat-containing macrophages) is nonspecific; raising the threshold to 30% may increase diagnostic accuracy.

 

Chest CT (Option A): Detects lung damage from emboli, but not fat specifically.

 

Intracranial Doppler ultrasonography (Option C): Detects cerebral emboli but not fat specifically.

 

Head CT (Option D): Identifies brain injury from emboli, not fat directly.

questions.text: A 60 y/o woman presents with sudden shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. She had a total hip replacement 10 days ago. O/E, she is tachycardic with low oxygen levels. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation:

  • Pulmonary embolism (PE) resulting from Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is the likely cause in this case.
  • Virchow's triad includes stasis, hypercoagulability, and endothelial injury.Together, these three factors significantly increase the risk of developing venous thromboembolism, which includes conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • The patient’s recent hip surgery and post-operative immobility significantly increase the risk of developing DVT in the lower limbs. Post-operative DVT and subsequent PE are common complications of joint replacement surgeries.
  • A blood clot from the deep veins can travel to the lungs, causing sudden symptoms such as dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, and hypoxemia, which align with this patient's presentation.

 

Pulmonary embolism (PE)

Causes

Pathophysiology

Most PE originates from deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the lower limbs.

Other rare causes include:

  • Septic emboli (from endocarditis affecting the tricuspid or pulmonary valves).
  • Fat emboli (after fractures of long bones, e.g., femur). (Option A)
  • Tumour emboli (e.g., choriocarcinoma). (Option B)
  • Air emboli (In ENT and neurosurgeries commonly) (Option C)
  • Amniotic fluid emboli (after delivery).

PE occurs when a blood clot (thrombus) travels to the lungs, blocking blood flow in the pulmonary artery.

Impaired Gas Exchange:

  • Increased anatomic and physiologic dead space due to decreased gas exchange.
  • Hypoxemia and increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient result from poor ventilation-perfusion matching.

Increased Pulmonary Vascular Resistance:

  • Vascular obstruction by the clot and release of vasoconstricting agents like serotonin.
  • Causes ventilation-perfusion mismatch even in areas away from the embolus.

Pulmonary Hypertension: Blockage of the pulmonary artery increases pressure, leading to strain on the right heart.

Right Ventricular (RV) Dysfunction:

  • RV dilatation and failure due to increased afterload.
  • RV microinfarction can occur with large PE, leading to elevated serum troponin and brain natriuretic peptide.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding causes of DVT is true?

choices.text: Factor V Leiden increases the effectiveness of activated protein C.
Prothrombin gene mutation decreases the concentration of prothrombin in the blood.
Cancer increases the risk of DVT fourfold compared to the general population.
Pregnancy reduces the risk of venous stasis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cancer increases the risk of DVT fourfold compared to the general population.

 

Explanation:

Risk Factors of Deep Vein Thrombosis

Inherited Thrombophilia

Acquired Risk Factors

Additional Factors

Genetic mutations that enhance clot formation, such as:

  • Factor V Leiden: Causes resistance to activated protein C, impairing its clot-regulating function. (Option A)
  • Prothrombin gene mutation: Increases prothrombin levels, promoting clot formation. (Option B)
  • Deficiencies: Rare deficiencies in anticoagulants like antithrombin, protein C, and protein S.
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome: An acquired disorder leading to an increased risk of venous and arterial thrombosis.
  • Cancer: The risk of DVT is about fourfold that of the general population, with approximately 15% of DVT cases linked to malignancies. (Option C)
  • Surgery: Major orthopaedic, abdominal, or neurological surgeries elevate DVT risk.
  • Pregnancy: Venous stasis and a hypercoagulable state during pregnancy increase DVT risk, especially postpartum. (Option D)
  • Immobility: Prolonged bed rest or long-distance travel can lead to venous stasis, contributing to DVT development.
  • Other Conditions: Obesity, smoking, hypertension, COPD, kidney disease, use of estrogen-based contraceptives, hormone replacement therapy, and trauma.
  • Age: The incidence of DVT rises with advancing age.
  • Sex: Females are at higher risk due to pregnancy and hormone use.
  • Ethnicity: May influence DVT risk.

questions.text: A 62 y/o hypertensive woman with a history of recent surgery presents with sudden onset of dyspnea and chest pain. ABG analysis reveals hypoxemia. A CT angiogram confirms the presence of a pulmonary embolism. What describes changes in the lung in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased physiologic dead space

 

Explanation:

Pulmonary Embolism leads to hypoxemia (low oxygen levels) due to disrupted gas exchange. It leads to the following:

  • Increased anatomic dead space: Air cannot reach functional alveoli.
  • Increased physiologic dead space: Air reaches alveoli, but there is inadequate blood flow for gas exchange. This leads to areas of the lung where air is present, but no corresponding blood flow is available to facilitate oxygen and carbon dioxide transfer.

 

Increased pulmonary compliance (Option A): In a pulmonary embolism, there is decreased lung compliance due to loss of surfactant and lung oedema.

 

Decreased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (Option B): PE results in an increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. While oxygen levels in the alveoli may remain high, the obstruction prevents adequate blood flow, leading to impaired gas exchange, and causing a significant difference between alveolar and arterial blood oxygen levels.

 

Improved gas exchange efficiency (Option D): The presence of a pulmonary embolism impairs gas exchange efficiency due to the obstruction of blood flow, resulting in impaired oxygenation of the blood and diminished overall lung function. There is airway resistance distal to the bronchi.

questions.text: A 45 y/o man presents with chest pain and dyspnea. A CT scan shows multiple pulmonary emboli. He is diagnosed with right ventricular dysfunction secondary to the emboli. Which of the following best explains the cause of the same?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Microinfarctions of the right ventricle

 

Explanation:

 

Hemodynamics in Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance

Right Ventricular Dysfunction
  • PE increases resistance in the pulmonary arteries due to:
    • Mechanical blockage by the embolus.
    • Substances like serotonin trigger vasoconstriction.
  • This increases strain on the right ventricle, potentially causing right ventricular failure.
  • Pulmonary hypertension may develop due to increased pulmonary vascular resistance.
  • PE can cause acute right ventricular dysfunction by increasing pressure in the pulmonary arteries.
  • Right ventricular wall tension increases and there is dilation of the right ventricle.
  • Emboli can lead to microinfarctions in the right ventricle due to increased pressure, leading to RV dysfunction. (Option B)

 

Left ventricular failure (Option A): Right ventricular dysfunction is due to increased resistance in the pulmonary arteries and microinfarctions caused by the emboli, rather than left heart issues. There is reduced cardiac output as the blood reaching the left ventricle decreases.

 

Decreased pulmonary vascular resistance (Option C): Pulmonary embolism leads to increased vascular resistance. The obstruction from the emboli causes an increase in RV wall tension and dilation resulting in strain and dysfunction.

 

Improved coronary perfusion (Option D): Pulmonary embolism results in reduced coronary perfusion. The strain on the right ventricle causes reduced blood flow to the coronary arteries, worsening the right ventricular function.

questions.text: A 58 y/o woman with a history of DVT presents to the hospital with sudden onset chest pain, tachycardia, and cyanosis. She is diagnosed with a massive pulmonary embolism. What is the most likely clinical finding that indicates acute cor pulmonale?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Jugular venous distention

 

Explanation:

Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a classic sign of right heart failure or acute cor pulmonale. It indicates fluid overload and pressure changes in the right atrium due to the inability of the right ventricle to handle the increased pulmonary artery pressure.

 

Acute Cor Pulmonale in Massive Pulmonary Thromboembolism

Acute cor pulmonale refers to right ventricular dysfunction due to a sudden rise in pulmonary artery pressure, often triggered by massive pulmonary embolism (PE).

Pathophysiology

Clinical Features

Diagnosis

  • Massive PE occurs when a large clot obstructs a portion of the pulmonary artery.
  • This obstruction results in a rapid increase in pulmonary vascular resistance, which the right ventricle must overcome.
  • The sudden pressure overload causes right ventricular dilation and impaired pumping efficiency.
  • Sudden collapse or syncope
  • Severe shortness of breath
  • Hypotension and tachycardia (Options C and D)
  • Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP)
  • Cyanosis
  • Signs of right heart failure and a prominent pulmonic component of the second heart sound (P2). (Option A)

Computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)- definitive diagnosis

 

Echocardiography:

  • Right ventricular dilation
  • A small left ventricle
  • Possible thrombus in the right ventricular outflow tract or pulmonary artery.
  • The McConnell sign indicates specific right ventricular dysfunction.

 

Pathophysiology:

Lung diseases and other causes
↓

Inflammation, fibrosis, hypoxia
↓

Increased arterial stiffness, endothelial dysfunction, vascular remodeling
↓

Persistent Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)
↓

Right Ventricular (RV) Hypertrophy, RV Failure
↓

Cor Pulmonale

questions.text: A 62 y/o male presents to the emergency with a history of prolonged immobility after recent hip surgery. His vital signs are as follows: respiratory rate of 28 bpm, heart rate of 110 bpm, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. D-dimer is 900 mg/dl, and CTPA shows filling defects. What is the most common symptom associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Unexplained dyspnea

 

Explanation:

The vital signs and imaging findings point to pulmonary embolism. Unexplained dyspnea, or shortness of breath without an apparent cause, is the most common symptom reported in patients with pulmonary embolism. It occurs due to impaired gas exchange and increased pulmonary artery pressure, making it a critical indicator of the condition.

 

Pulmonary Embolism - Clinical Features and Vitals Examination

Clinical Features

Vital Signs

  • Unexplained dyspnea
  • Pleuritic chest pain
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Apprehension.
  • Crushing central chest pain
  • Calf cramps

Severe Pulmonary Embolism:

  • Sudden collapse of the patient.
  • Severe hypotension
  • Cyanosis
  • Heart Rate: ↑
  • Respiratory Rate: ↑
  • Blood Pressure: ↓
  • Oxygen Saturation: ↓ (hypoxemia)
  • Temperature: ↑ (low-grade fever)

 

Syncope (Option A), Pleuritic chest pain (Option B), Hemoptysis (Option D): Although all are features of pulmonary embolism, they occur less frequently than unexplained dyspnea.

questions.text: A 62 y/o woman with a history of breast cancer is treated with chemotherapy. She presents with swelling and localised tenderness in her right leg. She was recently hospitalised for surgery and has been bedridden for the past three weeks. Examination shows pitting edema confined to the right leg, but no collateral veins and no previous DVT history. What is the patient's risk for DVT based on the Wells Criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) High probability

 

Explanation:

Scoring Breakdown:

  • Active cancer (1 point)
  • Recently bedridden (1 point)
  • Localized tenderness (1 point)
  • Entire leg swelling (1 point)
  • Pitting oedema (1 point)

Total Score = 5 (High probability for DVT Score 3-8).


 

Wells Criteria for Prediction of DVT

Clinical Characteristic

Score

Active cancer (patient either receiving treatment for cancer within the previous 6 months or currently receiving palliative treatment)

1

Paralysis, paresis, or recent cast immobilization of the lower extremities

1

Recently bedridden for ≥ 3 days, or major surgery within the previous 12 weeks

1

Localized tenderness along the deep venous system

1

Entire leg swelling

1

Calf swelling at least 3 cm larger than that on the asymptomatic side (measured 10 cm below tibial tuberosity)

1

Pitting oedema confined to the symptomatic leg

1

Collateral superficial veins (non-varicose)

1

Previously documented DVT

1

Alternative diagnosis at least as likely as DVT

-2

Wells scoring system

Deep vein thrombosis unlikely if Score ≤1 (Option A)

Deep Venous Thrombosis is likely if the Score >1

(Or)

-2 to 0: Low probability (Option B)

1 to 2 points: Moderate probability (Option C)

3 to 8 points: High Probability

questions.text: A 65y/o man presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and mild hypotension. His echocardiogram shows right ventricular (RV) dysfunction, but his systemic arterial pressure remains normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Catheter-directed thrombolysis

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms of pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and echocardiographic evidence of right ventricular (RV) dysfunction without hypotension suggest submassive pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • Catheter-directed thrombolysis (C) is preferred in this case due to lower bleeding risk, particularly in elderly patients or those with contraindications to systemic thrombolysis.

 

Pulmonary Infarction

Submassive Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
  • Indicates a small PE, causing severe pleuritic pain due to peripheral thrombus near pleural nerves.
  • Pain may radiate to the right upper quadrant or supraclavicular area, mimicking abdominal emergencies.
  • Can result from thrombotic or nonthrombotic causes (e.g., fat embolism, tumour embolism, bone marrow, air embolism).
  • Possible imaging findings: peripheral wedge-shaped opacity, enlarged pulmonary artery, or regional vascular oliguria.
  • Typically treated with observation and imaging such as a CT angiogram to confirm diagnosis.
  • Accounts for 20–25% of PE cases, characterised by right ventricular (RV) dysfunction but normal systemic arterial pressure.
  • Common signs: dyspnea, hypotension, syncope, right heart failure, and elevated cardiac biomarkers like troponin.
  • Can deteriorate clinically if untreated; associated with increased risk of heart failure.
  • Fibrinolytic therapy lowers the rate of recurrence of PE. It helps by dissolving clots, reducing pulmonary hypertension, and addressing deep vein thrombus sources.
  • Standard tPA dosing is 100 mg over 2 hours, with lower doses (50 mg over 2 hours) reducing bleeding risks. Major bleeding risk is the risk of intracranial haemorrhage.
  • Pharmacomechanical catheter-directed therapy uses thrombus fragmentation with low-dose thrombolysis (e.g., 24 mg alteplase over 12 hours) to decrease RV dilation, pulmonary hypertension, and lower complication risks.

 

Immediate anticoagulation and observation (Option A): While anticoagulation is necessary, observation alone may not be sufficient to address RV dysfunction, which could worsen without further intervention.

 

Fibrinolytic therapy (Option B): Systemic fibrinolysis is generally reserved for massive PE with hemodynamic collapse and carries higher bleeding risks, particularly intracranial haemorrhage.

 

Surgical embolectomy (Option D): Typically reserved for massive PE or cases refractory to thrombolysis, surgical embolectomy is too invasive for submassive PE with stable systemic pressure.

questions.text: A 60 y/o male with a history of recent surgery presents with acute onset dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. His ECG findings show sinus tachycardia. Which of the following investigations would most directly confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CT pulmonary angiogram

 

Explanation:

CT pulmonary angiogram is the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism, as it allows direct visualization of the pulmonary arteries and identification of any occlusions.

 

Investigations for Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Clinical Evaluation:

PE symptoms are nonspecific, often leading to excessive use of CT pulmonary angiograms. Age-adjusted d-dimer testing is recommended for patients over 50 years with low-to-moderate PE probability.

D-Dimer:

A sensitive but nonspecific test for PE. Elevated levels indicate possible PE but can also occur with conditions like MI, pneumonia, or sepsis. Normal d-dimer helps rule out PE. (Option D)

Electrocardiogram (ECG):
  • Common findings include sinus tachycardia(most common) and the S1Q3T3 sign(most specific) (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III, inverted T wave in lead III).
  • T-wave inversion in V1 to V4 suggests RV strain or ischemia.

Venous Ultrasonography:
  • Uses loss of vein compressibility as a key indicator for diagnosing DVT, which is associated with PE.
  • Doppler imaging can assess blood flow dynamics.

Chest X-ray:

Often normal but may show specific signs like Westermark’s sign (focal oligemia), Hampton’s hump (wedge-shaped pleural density), or Palla’s sign (enlarged pulmonary artery).

Chest radiograph demonstrating focal oligemia (Westermark’s sign) in the right lung (area between white arrowheads) and a prominent right descending pulmonary artery (Palla’s sign) (black arrow).

 

The chest radiograph demonstrates a wedge-shaped opacity (arrow) in the right middle lobe consistent with Hampton hump.

Chest CT with Contrast:
  • The primary imaging test. It offers high-resolution visualisation of pulmonary vasculature.
  • RV enlargement on CT indicates a higher risk of mortality.

Lung Scanning:

A second-line test, mostly for patients who can’t tolerate contrast. High-probability perfusion scans (two or more segmental perfusion defects) strongly suggest PE.

Magnetic Resonance (MR) Imaging:

MR venography with gadolinium can diagnose DVT when ultrasound is inconclusive, though MR pulmonary angiography is less reliable for smaller PEs.

Echocardiography:

It is not reliable for directly diagnosing PE but useful for detecting mimicking conditions. McConnell’s sign (RV-free wall hypokinesis) is an indirect sign of PE.

Pulmonary Angiography:

Identifies intraluminal filling defects or abrupt vessel occlusion.

 

Chest X-ray (Option A): A chest X-ray can show indirect signs of PE, such as Westermark's sign or Hampton's hump, but it cannot definitively confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.

 

Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan (Option B): A V/Q scan can suggest the likelihood of PE by showing mismatched perfusion defects, but it is not as definitive as other imaging modalities.

questions.text: A 70 y/o woman with a history of atrial fibrillation presents to the ED with sudden onset dyspnea and sharp chest pain. Her chest X-ray reveals a wedge-shaped opacity in the right middle lobe as shown. She exhibits signs of hypotension, tachycardia, and altered mental status. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Starting her on intravenous unfractionated heparin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Administration of thrombolytic therapy

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with sudden onset dyspnea, sharp chest pain, hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status, and chest X-ray findings of a wedge-shaped opacity in the right middle lobe indicative of Hampton’s hump, all indicative of massive pulmonary embolism.
  • Administration of thrombolytic therapy is the most appropriate initial management because it rapidly dissolves the obstructing clot, addressing the severe hemodynamic instability and potentially life-threatening situation presented by the massive PE.

Pulmonary Embolism (PE) Treatment

Risk Stratification:
  • Hemodynamic instability, right ventricular (RV) dysfunction, and elevated troponins indicate high risk.
  • Stable patients with normal RV function have a favourable prognosis with anticoagulation alone.

Anticoagulation (foundation of treatment):
  • Three Major Strategies:
    • Parenteral anticoagulation (UFH, LMWH, or fondaparinux).
    • Parenteral therapy is followed by novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) like dabigatran or edoxaban.
    • Oral monotherapy with NOACs (rivaroxaban, apixaban).
  • Unfractionated Heparin (UFH): Requires aPTT monitoring, useful for close control.
  • Low-Molecular-Weight Heparin (LMWH): Predictable dose-response, no monitoring unless in obesity or CKD.
  • Fondaparinux: A weight-based daily injection, no monitoring needed.
  • Warfarin: Vitamin K antagonist, requires INR monitoring (target 2.0–3.0).
  • Novel Oral Anticoagulants (NOACs): Fixed doses, rapid action, no need for monitoring

IVC Filters:
  • Indications: Active bleeding preventing anticoagulation or recurrent thrombosis despite anticoagulation.
  • Retrievable filters are preferred over permanent ones.

Massive PE Management:
  • The treatment of massive pulmonary embolism (PE) involves systemic thrombolysis (ST) with agents like tPA, typically at a dose of 100 mg over 2 hours, or a reduced dose of 50 mg in patients with contraindications
  • Fluid resuscitation (cautious), norepinephrine for vasopressor support, and dobutamine for RV inotropy.
  • Consider ECMO for severe cases as a bridge to thrombolysis or embolectomy.

Fibrinolysis:
  • Used to rapidly reverse RV failure and dissolve clots.
  • Systemic regimen: 100 mg tPA over 2 hours; lower doses (50 mg) may reduce bleeding risk.

Pharmacomechanical Catheter-Directed Therapy:
  • Combines thrombolysis with mechanical fragmentation (ultrasound-facilitated, maceration, suction).
  • Lower doses of thrombolytics are used, reducing complications.

Surgical Embolectomy:

  • Resurgence due to improved survival.
  • Indicated for patients with massive PE when other treatments fail. (Option D)

Initiation of oral anticoagulation (Option A): Oral anticoagulation is inappropriate for acute management in the setting of significant clinical instability; immediate treatment is necessary to stabilize the patient.

Starting her on intravenous unfractionated heparin (Option B): While unfractionated heparin is effective in managing pulmonary embolism, it is not the first-line treatment in a patient showing signs of hemodynamic instability, where rapid intervention is crucial.

questions.text: A 72 y/o woman presents to the ED with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain. On examination, she is hypotensive (systolic BP 85 mm Hg), has tachycardia, and exhibits signs of altered consciousness. An echocardiogram shows right ventricular (RV) dysfunction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Massive pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation:

The patient demonstrates systemic hypotension, altered consciousness, and echocardiographic evidence of RV dysfunction, all indicating massive PE.

Pulmonary Embolism (PE) Classification

 

Massive PE

Submassive PE

Non-massive PE
  • Defined by systemic hypotension (systolic arterial pressure < 90 mm Hg or a drop of ≥40 mm Hg for at least 15 minutes).
  • Associated with shock (evidence of tissue hypoperfusion, altered consciousness, oliguria, cold/clammy extremities).
  • High mortality despite advances in diagnosis and therapy.
  • Diagnosis through echocardiography shows RV dysfunction and other clinical signs like neck vein distension.
  • Rapid intervention is critical as 50% die within 30 minutes, and more than 85% within 6 hours of symptom onset.
  • Hemodynamic instability; requires immediate supportive measures, thrombolysis, or surgical intervention.
  • Normotensive but presents with right ventricular (RV) dysfunction or hypokinesis confirmed by echocardiography.
  • Carries a worse prognosis than non-massive PE with normal RV function but better than massive PE.
  • RV dysfunction: Identified through echo with parameters such as RV dilation, pulmonary hypertension, and McConnell's sign (akinesia of RV free wall with spared apex).
  • Troponin and BNP markers are often elevated; both are useful for risk stratification.
  • The role of thrombolysis is controversial and patient-specific.
  • Anticoagulation is essential.
  • Normotensive and no evidence of RV dysfunction or hypokinesis.
  • Better overall prognosis with lower risk of mortality and complications.
  • Can present with non-specific clinical symptoms but is stable hemodynamically.
  • Treated mainly with anticoagulation, without the need for thrombolytics or more aggressive therapies.

 

Submassive pulmonary embolism (Option A): This option is unlikely because the patient is hypotensive and exhibits altered consciousness, which is more characteristic of massive PE rather than submassive PE, which generally lacks hemodynamic instability.

 

Pneumonia (Option C): While pneumonia can cause chest pain and dyspnea, the hypotension and altered mental status in this scenario point away from this diagnosis, as pneumonia typically does not lead to significant hemodynamic instability.

 

Myocardial infarction (Option D): Although myocardial infarction can present with chest pain and hypotension, the echocardiographic findings of RV dysfunction align more closely with massive pulmonary embolism rather than MI.

questions.text: A 28 y/o man is admitted to the ED following a motorcycle accident resulting in multiple fractures of the right femur and left humerus. Two days post-injury, he developed sudden onset dyspnea, altered mental status, and a petechial rash around his neck and conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES)

 

Explanation:

Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) is the most likely diagnosis, given the recent trauma, respiratory distress, altered mental status, and petechial rash, which are characteristic signs of FES. Symptoms often develop within 24-72 hours following fat emboli entering circulation.

  • Histopathological image

Fat Embolism Causes
  • Blunt trauma: Accounts for 90% of cases, especially involving extremity fractures.
  • Associated conditions:
    • Acute pancreatitis
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Burns
    • Joint reconstruction surgeries
    • Liposuction
    • Cardiopulmonary bypass
    • Decompression sickness
    • Parenteral lipid infusion
    • Sickle cell crisis
    • Pathologic fractures
  • Increased risk factors (in trauma patients):
    • Age 30 years or younger
    • Closed femur fracture
    • Multiple long-bone fractures

 

Pathophysiology of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES):

  • Mechanism: Not fully understood but involves fat emboli entering circulation, usually after major trauma or surgical procedures (e.g., intramedullary nailing).
  • Pulmonary effects:
    • Fat emboli occlude microvasculature, leading to inflammatory responses and endothelial injury.
    • Pulmonary consequences mimic acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), presenting within 24 hours with symptoms of respiratory failure.
    • Fatty acids released from emboli increase vascular permeability, causing alveolar haemorrhage and oedema.
  • Systemic effects:
    • Involvement of the brain and kidneys, especially in patients with patent foramen ovale
    • Neurologic symptoms include encephalopathy and cerebral oedema due to cerebral vasculature occlusion.

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) (Option A): While the patient shows respiratory failure, the combination of recent trauma, neurologic symptoms, and the petechial rash is more indicative of Fat Embolism Syndrome rather than ARDS alone, which does not typically present with a rash.

 

Pulmonary Embolism (PE) (Option C): Though PE can present with sudden dyspnea and hypoxia, it does not typically cause neurologic symptoms or petechial rash, making FES a more fitting diagnosis in this case.

 

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) (Option D): While DVT is a risk in trauma patients, it usually presents with leg swelling and pain rather than respiratory symptoms and altered mental status, which are not typical manifestations of DVT.

questions.text: A 28 y/o male presents to the ED after sustaining multiple long bone fractures in a motorcycle accident. Two days post-injury, he exhibits tachypnea, confusion, and a petechial rash on his torso. Which of the following is NOT a part of the diagnostic criteria for the patient's likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Elevated white blood cell count
 

Explanation:

  • The patient's recent history of long-bone fractures, along with the characteristic clinical features of tachypnea, confusion, and a petechial rash that developed 24-36 hours post-injury indicates Fat embolism syndrome.
  • While an elevated white blood cell count may indicate an inflammatory response, it is not included in the major or minor diagnostic criteria for FES.

 

Gurd and Wilson's Diagnostic Criteria:

One major criterion, four minor criteria, and the presence of macroglobulinemia are required for the diagnosis.

 

Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Respiratory insufficiency (symptoms and radiologic evidence)
  • Cerebral dysfunction not caused by head injury or other conditions
  • Petechial rash
  • Tachycardia (>110 beats/min)
  • Pyrexia (temperature >38.5°C)
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Jaundice
  • Acute drop in haemoglobin
  • Sudden thrombocytopenia
  • Elevated ESR
  • Fat macroglobulinemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining multiple long bone fractures in a car accident. Two days later, he developed respiratory distress, confusion, and a petechial rash. His oxygen saturation is dropping, and the medical team begins supportive care, including fluid resuscitation and monitoring. Which of the following is the best option for expanding plasma volume and potentially limiting lung injury in this patient with FES?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Albumin
 

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) due to the patient's history of multiple long-bone fractures followed by respiratory distress, confusion, and a petechial rash, all occurring within a typical time frame post-injury.
  • Albumin provides greater plasma volume expansion and may help limit lung injury by binding fatty acids, making it the best choice for managing fluid resuscitation in FES.

Fat Embolism Treatment:

There is no definitive treatment.

 

Supportive Medical Care
  • Adequate oxygenation and ventilation
  • Maintain hemodynamic stability through appropriate fluid resuscitation.
  • Hydration, blood product administration, DVT prophylaxis, and stress ulcer prevention are essential.
  • Continuous pulse oximetry monitoring in at-risk patients.

Intravenous Fluids
  • Isotonic crystalloids (e.g., normal saline, Ringer lactate) are used for initial volume resuscitation.
  • Colloids (e.g., albumin) provide greater plasma volume expansion, reduce pulmonary and cerebral oedema, and may bind fatty acids to limit lung injury.

Corticosteroids
  • May reduce morbidity in some cases
  • Methylprednisolone is commonly used for prophylaxis in at-risk patients

Surgical Management
  • Early stabilization of long bone fractures (within 24 hours) minimizes fat embolization and reduces the risk of FES.
  • Techniques like vacuum or venting during reaming of bone can decrease fat embolism.
  • In high-risk cases, prophylactic placement of inferior vena cava filters may prevent fat emboli from reaching the heart.

 

Normal saline (Option A): While effective for initial fluid resuscitation, it does not provide the oncotic support necessary to limit lung injury compared to colloids.

 

Ringer lactate solution (Option B): This isotonic crystalloid is useful for fluid resuscitation but lacks the specific properties to bind fatty acids and expand plasma volume as effectively as albumin.

 

Corticosteroids (Option D): Although they may reduce inflammation, they do not specifically expand plasma volume or directly address fluid resuscitation needs.
